answer_html: \(\int_0^{10} 2\pi \underbrace{r}_{=u}50\underbrace{\sin\left(\frac{\pi r}{10}\right)dr}_{dv}=10000.\) There are 10000 seeds around the tree.
answer_latex: $\int_0^{10} 2\pi \underbrace{r}_{=u}50\underbrace{\sin\left(\frac{\pi r}{10}\right)dr}_{dv}=10000.$ There are 10000 seeds around the tree.
hints_html:
We have the density \(s\) of seeds per \(m^2\) given and are searching for the number of seeds. So, an integral must be involved in the calculation.

The seeds lay radially symmetric around the tree. So, it is a circular area with radius \(10m\), where the seeds are distributed.

The volume of the seeds are a solid of revolution with the function \(s(r)\) rotated around the tree (=y-axis).

For the solid of revolution use the shell method \(\int 2\pi x h(x)dx\).

For the integration use integration by parts.

the number of seeds. So, an integral must be involved in the
calculation.

area with radius $10m$, where the seeds are distributed.

The volume of the seeds are a solid of revolution with the function
$s(r)$ rotated around the tree (=y-axis).

For the solid of revolution use the shell method $\int 2\pi x h(x)dx$.

For the integration use integration by parts.
hints_raw:
We have the density <math>\ s</math> of seeds per <math>\ m^2</math> given and are searching for the number of seeds. So, an integral must be involved in the calculation.
The seeds lay radially symmetric around the tree. So, it is a circular area with radius <math>\ 10m</math>, where the seeds are distributed.

The volume of the seeds are a solid of revolution with the function <math>\ s(r)</math> rotated around the tree (=y-axis).
For the solid of revolution use the shell method <math>\ \int 2\pi x h(x)dx</math>. 

For the integration use integration by parts.
question: 6 (b)
sols_html:
The total number of seeds is the sum of all \(m^2\) around the tree times the passend concentration of seeds.

Because the area around the tree is a ring, the field of seeds looks like a the function rotated around the tree (y-axis).

To calculate this integral, we use the shell method \(\displaystyle \int 2\pi xh(x)dx\)

For integration we use integration by parts.

\[\begin{aligned} \int_0^{10} 2\pi \underbrace{r}_{=u}50\underbrace{\sin\left(\frac{\pi r}{10}\right)dr}_{dv} &= 100\pi\left[\left.-r\cos\left(\frac{\pi r}{10}\right)\frac{10}{\pi}\right|_0^{10} + \frac{10}{\pi}\int_0^{10}\cos\left(\frac{\pi r}{10}\right)dr\right]\\ &= 100\left[-10\cdot 10\cos(\pi) + 0 + 10\left.\sin\left(\frac{\pi r}{10}\right)\frac{10}{\pi}\right|_0^{10}\right]\\ &= 10000.\end{aligned}\]

There are 10000 seeds around the tree.
sols_latex:
The total number of seeds is the sum of all $m^2$ around the tree times
the passend concentration of seeds.

\includegraphics[width=0.5\textwidth]{../json_data/MATH103/April_2009/Math_Exam_Resources_Courses_MATH103_April_2009_Question_6_(b)_picture_1.jpg}

Because the area around the tree is a ring, the field of seeds looks
like a the function rotated around the tree (y-axis).

To calculate this integral, we use the shell method
$\displaystyle \int 2\pi xh(x)dx$

For integration we use integration by parts.

\begin{align*}
\int_0^{10} 2\pi \underbrace{r}_{=u}50\underbrace{\sin\left(\frac{\pi r}{10}\right)dr}_{dv} &= 
100\pi\left[\left.-r\cos\left(\frac{\pi r}{10}\right)\frac{10}{\pi}\right|_0^{10} + 
\frac{10}{\pi}\int_0^{10}\cos\left(\frac{\pi r}{10}\right)dr\right]\\
&= 100\left[-10\cdot 10\cos(\pi) + 0 + 10\left.\sin\left(\frac{\pi r}{10}\right)\frac{10}{\pi}\right|_0^{10}\right]\\
&= 10000.
\end{align*}

There are 10000 seeds around the tree.
sols_raw:
The total number of seeds is the sum of all <math>\ m^2</math> around the tree times the passend concentration of seeds.

[[File:Math_Exam_Resources_Courses_MATH103_April_2009_Question_6_(b)_picture_1.jpg|250px|right]]


Because the area around the tree is a ring, the field of seeds looks like a the function rotated around the tree (y-axis).

To calculate this integral, we use the shell method
<math>\displaystyle \int 2\pi xh(x)dx</math>

For integration we use integration by parts.

<math>\begin{align}
\int_0^{10} 2\pi \underbrace{r}_{=u}50\underbrace{\sin\left(\frac{\pi r}{10}\right)dr}_{dv} &= 
100\pi\left[\left.-r\cos\left(\frac{\pi r}{10}\right)\frac{10}{\pi}\right|_0^{10} + 
\frac{10}{\pi}\int_0^{10}\cos\left(\frac{\pi r}{10}\right)dr\right]\\
&= 100\left[-10\cdot 10\cos(\pi) + 0 + 10\left.\sin\left(\frac{\pi r}{10}\right)\frac{10}{\pi}\right|_0^{10}\right]\\
&= 10000.
\end{align}</math>

There are 10000 seeds around the tree.
statement_html:
Seeds are dispersed from a tree in all directions uniformly. The density of seeds that lands on the ground at a distance r away is approximately described by the function

\[\begin{aligned} s(r) = 50 \sin\left(\frac{\pi r}{10}\right) \text{ seeds/m}^2, \quad 0 \leq r \leq 10 \text{ m}\end{aligned}\]

What is the total number of seeds on the ground within a 10 m radius of the tree?
statement_raw:
Seeds are dispersed from a tree in all directions uniformly. The density of seeds that lands on the ground at a distance ''r'' away is approximately described by the function

:<math> s(r) = 50 \sin\left(\frac{\pi r}{10}\right) \text{ seeds/m}^2, \quad 0 \leq r \leq 10 \text{ m} </math>

What is the total number of seeds on the ground within a 10 m radius of the tree?
